cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 77 (Friday, May 5, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. FRY:H.R. 3091.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8 of the United States ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:Second Amendment[Page H2137]

item.title: Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2494) to make the assault of a law enforcement officer a deportable offense, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3091) to allow Federal law enforcement officers to purchase retired service weapons, and for other purposes; and providing for consideration of the concurrent resolution (H. Con. Res. 40) expressing support for local law enforcement officers and condemning efforts to defund or dismantle local law enforcement agencies.

latestAction.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

item.title: Federal Law Enforcement Service Weapon Purchase Act

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

item.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On passage Passed by recorded vote: 232 - 198 (Roll no. 222).
Passed/agreed to in House: On passage Passed by recorded vote: 232 - 198 (Roll no. 222).
The House adopted the amendment in the nature of a substitute as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 3091.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.
Considered as unfinished business. (consideration: CR H2401-2405)
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 3091 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Fry moved that the committee rise.

POSTPONED PROCEEDINGS - At the conclusion of debate on the Rosendale amendment No. 4, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Nadler demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 398, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Rosendale amendment No. 4.

POSTPONED PROCEEDINGS - At the conclusion of debate on the Luttrell amendment No. 3, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Nadler demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed proceedings until a time to be announced.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 398, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Luttrell amendment No. 3.

POSTPONED PROCEEDINGS - At the conclusion of debate on the McCormick amendment No. 2, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Nadler demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 398, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the McCormick amendment No. 2.

POSTPONED PROCEEDINGS - At the conclusion of debate on the Jacobs amendment No. 1, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced the noes had prevailed. Ms. Jacobs demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 398, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Jacobs amendment No. 1.
GENERAL DEBATE - The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 3091.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mike Garcia to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 398 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 2494, H.R. 3091 and H. Con. Res. 40. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 2494 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate; H.R. 3091 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate; and H.Con.Res. 40 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate. The resolution provides for a motion to recommit on H.R. 2494 and H.R. 3091.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 398. (consideration: CR H2389-2394; text: CR H2390-2391)

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 398 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 2494, H.R. 3091 and H. Con. Res. 40. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 2494 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate; H.R. 3091 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate; and H.Con.Res. 40 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate. The resolution provides for a motion to recommit on H.R. 2494 and H.R. 3091.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 39.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 118-58.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 118-58.
Ordered to be Reported (Amended) by Voice Vote.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.
Introduced in House

item.title: H.R. 3091, Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act
item.description: As ordered reported by the House Committee on the Judiciary on May 10, 2023

item.title: H.R. 3091, Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act
item.description: As ordered reported by the House Committee on the Judiciary on May 10, 2023

cdata.text:
Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act

This bill directs the General Services Administration to establish a program under which a federal law enforcement officer may purchase a retired handgun from the agency that issued the handgun to the officer.

Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act

This bill directs the General Services Administration to establish a program under which a federal law enforcement officer may purchase a retired handgun from the agency that issued the handgun to the officer.

Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act

This bill directs the General Services Administration to establish a program under which a federal law enforcement officer may purchase a retired firearm from the agency that issued the firearm to the officer.

Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act

item.titleType: Short Title(s) as Reported to House
item.title: Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act
Federal Law Enforcement Officer Service Weapon Purchase Act
To allow Federal law enforcement officers to purchase retired service weapons, and for other purposes.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 4 printed in Part B of House Report 118-59 to expand the types of weapons officers are allowed to purchase to include all retired firearms.
amendment.purpose: Amendment expands the types of weapons officers are allowed to purchase to include all retired firearms.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 3 printed in Part B of House Report 118-59 to allow retired federal law enforcement officers to also be eligible to purchase retired service weapons.
amendment.purpose: Amendment allows retired federal law enforcement officers to also be eligible to purchase retired service weapons.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 2 printed in Part B of House Report to strike "fair market value" and replace it with "salvage value," which is defined as the value of an asset at the end of its useful life.
amendment.purpose: Amendment ensures to strike "fair market value" and replace it with "salvage value", which is defined as the value of an asset at the end of its useful life.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 1 printed in Part B of House Report 118-59 to require each federal agency to establish determinations for an officer in good standing.
amendment.purpose: Amendment sought to require each Federal agency to establish determinations for an officer in good standing.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
